review_body: Very basic and affordable hostel if you want to have a safe friendly bed and breakfast option in Tokyo. We had 2 bunk beds (super-soft dawn duvets) in our room for the family of 4, powerful showers on the same floor and several toilets, wash basins, laundry, bar and reception. All facilities are available 24/7. Linen changed daily with clean kimono and small towel provided daily. Basic breakfast included. Coffee was natural and very tasty! Juices and fancy teas are also available. Staff know several languages and nothing is too much trouble for whatever your request. I found them all so very helpful and friendly. They will advise you on all the maps and local events and attractions and transport issues. Great place to stay!

The staff were amazing and very helpful which was much appreciated as this was my first stop in Japan. The facility is clean and the twin private room on the main floor was great. The only suggestion for improvement that I have is the ladder on the bunk bed to have flat steps instead. The small round steps are hard on the feet. Would certainly stay here again and recommend to anyone.

I stayed here for a few nights. The staffs are friendly and this place is suite for person who want to take away from complicated town. Around here is the old book town. There're some ramen restaurants. The taste is ok and reasonable price.

The place is 2 minutes away by subway from tokio station, Well locatedThey have a very acurate description on how to get there from the T.S. surrounded by nice places to eat and lots of old book stores.Although they answered my reservation in spanish and were very kind to keep in touch in my language they didnt have spanish spoken staff but i understand it´s difficult to cover all aspects. Staff can speak very good english and they help me very much with all my questions about where to go and when i ask for a taxi for the next day. Very helpful and friendly. Great attitude unfortunelly i only stayed one nightAlthough they are shared, badrooms are very clean. I asked for a private room, very clean and neat, the only "but" i could find is that because is a very closed space i think, it smell a litle bit like humidity,I´d like to thank the staff for all their help.i definetly recomend it very much.

Hotel is close to subway and local stores: Family Mart and 7eleven. There is small restaurant with nice food. Breakfast are simple but ok. There is a coin laundry and dryier. It cost 300 yen and 100 yen. Rooms are small but enough for a few days. It would be nice to have free coffee and tea all day or at least hot water like it is in other places.

It was really comfortable. Everything was clean. The breakfast really delicious. Staff always willing to help you. We even celebrate a birthday there and they gave him a present. It was a really awesome stay. I would totally come back!

A bit further from the tourist spots (e.g.Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ginza).We go by metro, and stop at Jimbocho Station (3 lines for this station), & manage to find the hotel using Waze (a GPS app on mobile).We booked the room a few months ago via Expedia, got it at low price compared to other hotels in Tokyo.We booked a semi-double room, and the room is small for the two of us (me & my sister).The bathrooms & toilets are on share basis, i.e. 2 bathrooms, 2 male toilets, 2 female toilets & 2 sinks for each floor.Breakfast is included and with free Wi-Fi. They have a restaurant at ground floor which also is the common area for the room guests.Many restaurants and one convenient store next to the hotel.Staff are friendly too, as usual! Loving their hospitality.

This hotel and hostel is nothing fancy, but had clean beds and helpful staff. Met some nice people who stayed in the same room as me. Good location and easy to get anywhere with Jimbocho station only about a 2 minute walk away. Breakfast buffet isn't really much of a buffet, but is super inexpensive. I would stay here again because I think the location is very central to do many different things in Tokyo.

We stayed here as a family with two adults and two kids. It's a long time since we (the parents) have stayed in any hostels and shared bathrooms but the astronomical cost of accommodation during cherry blossom season forced us back to hostels. It was not a bad experience. Hostels have changed a lot since our backpacking days (20 years ago). For starters, they are a lot more expensive now in Japan. But this place was also clean, the breakfast was adequate, probably slightly better than expected for the price. Our private room had 2 bunk beds (4 beds in total) and another separate single bed. The washing machine and dryer in the basement (coin operated) was appreciated by us as we needed to do a lot of washing in Japan. If back in Tokyo, I would probably try and find somewhere on the JR Yamanote line. From what I could tell, we were the only family staying there. The other guests were local Japanese graduates attending a nearby job fair (my guess); a few groups of 5 or more people, and some individuals. Not a typical backpacking hostel crowd.

Travelled with eldest son to celebrate his graduation. Absolutely fabulous Hostel/Hotel.Small rooms but perfectly adequate for our needs. Met many new friends from across the globe in a welcoming friendly atmosphere. Would recommend to anyone wanting a cheap base to visit this awesome city.

The Sakura Hotel and Hostel in Jinbocho features a shared bathroom on each floor, only two laundry machines and instead of the Yamanote Line, you have to take the subway. Personally, I thought it would be a hassle but instead, I enjoyed my stay at Jinbocho. And the price I received for two weeks, I definitely saved a lot of money and it really helped as it allowed me to have much more money to use on shopping and more money for my Suica Card.But the reason why I chose this location was to be in a different part of Japan that is more business oriented but also wanted something that could fit my budget but also close to Tokyo Dome.

Nice room, the dorm is nice. Shower rooms and toilet are small but enough for use, and clean.The room is small cozy, good for youth travellers, but not quite match with family travelling with many luggages. There's toasts complete set, jams, toaster machine, soup, coffee and cold beverages, Mountain Dew is here！The staffs are friendly and helpful, fluent in english. Good place to meet new friends from around the world. Very close to Jimbocho Station （not JR line）, and quite a walk to Ochanomizu Station （JR line）around 15mins pass through the Meiji University. A place to just rest at night, and prepares you to venture Tokyo in the morning.

This hotel is very close to the city centre or the Imperial palace as a guidepost. It's only about 5 minutes walk away from the closest subway station. This is a hotel/hostel kind of facility so if you're looking for a Hyatt style hotel, you'd best look else where and pay way more. Bathroom and toilets are shared per floor. Our floor - 6th have 2 toilet stalls for men and 2 for women. There are also 2 shower alcoves for each floor. Bathroom sink and mirror are literally in the hall ways. Room is small but sufficient and beds are comfortable and clean with soft blankets. Lobby has a small front desk the right when you walk in and to the left is a small seating area for breakfast. A simple breakfast (toast, jam, coffee can be included for a small fee when you check in) but other more extravagant items, ie. eggs, meat will be charged even more when you ordered them from the front desk. Best to just step out and get more variety of food.There are quite a few interesting food establishments within a few minutes walking distance of the hotel and because it is near the center point of the city, areas such as Shinjuku and other centre of activities are all but a few stations ride away.Pros: close to city centre/subway, no frill price, friendly staffCons: shared lavatories and showersThis is a descent place to stay in Tokyo if you're on a budget and want to stay close to the city.

The internet here was garbage. Yes, you connected to a router. No, you didn't receive functional internet. The internet speed was clocked at a staggering 0.12 Mbps on a Wednesday afternoon when nobody was around. That is as slow as dial-up. In 2016! In Japan! Also, the pleace feels like a college dormitory for the dorkiest weirdos ever. Total melvins stay here. Walls were dirty in room. All around mediocre. Had my own room and all I expected at a hostel-style place is a clean room, functional internet and a little bit of quiet. This place provided none of these. Just as a point of reference to illustrate that I am not a rookie traveler, I have been staying at hostels for the last 13 months in a trip around the world; hundreds of them and this one is in the bottom 5.

This hotel was perfect for my stay in Tokyo, very close to the underground in a quiet area off the main highway, a short walk from Akihabara. Reception staff were very helpful with our needs and friendly. Needed to change rooms and was done with minimal hassle. Good little coffee shop downstairs, and easy to meet other travellers!

We booked the Twin Room for our stay between 5 to10 Dec 2015.The Hotel is near the Jimbocho Subway Train Station. The Hotel Staff can speak in English. There is a lift to access the different levels. The wifi is the room is good. No towels are provided. But a small hand towel is given. The room is clean and the beds are comfortable. There is a TV but no kettle and fridge.The toilets and bathrooms are in the hallway of each floor to be shared. They are clean.In all, our stay there was pleasant.

This is the best hostel in tokyo, quite hostel n i met nice peoples around the world n talked about everything. There is a halloween party when i stayed there. You can find a supermarket n food around this hostel. You just 5minutes to jimbocho subway.

This was the third time I have stayed at the Sakura over the past 12 years. It remains a hassle free place to stay. It hs a 24 hour cafe downstairs and the staff are incredibly helpful and friendly.Up the road (50 meters) are Thai and Pizza restaurants and around the corner, the ubiquitous convenience store and even a craft beer market! Jimbocho station is close by and it provided safe and trouble free accommodation once again.Sakata and obie are on each bed as well as small wash cloth, changed daily with linen. Showers (shared) have liquid soap and shampoo and are cleaned daily. The included breakfast is simple and can be supplemented with other items from the cafe. However, there are so many things to eat in this area, going hungry wont be a problem, unless you don't want to try anything different!I would be happy to stay there again.

Stayed here for 8 nights in a Twin room (which actually consisted of 3 beds- a bunk bed and a single bed) not sure if we got bumped up to a bigger room because we only booked for 2 people but i was not complaining, it was the most spacious room I stayed at whilst traveling Japan! The room is cleaned every day- sheets are changed too which was great to come back to every night after a big day of site seeing! The free wifi worked well our whole stay and the shared bathrooms and toilets were cleaned every day. In our room (302) We had an aircon, a vent, a tv, individual lights (which came in handy on the bunk beds) and windows you could actually open (you'd be surprised how many japanese hotels and guesthouses don't have windows and natural air phew) They also have a cafe downstairs which is open 24/7Location is great- I love the Jimbocho area with all the quirky bookstores and markets on weekends. So many cafes and restaurants in this area, you won't be stuck for food. There is also a 7/11 around the corner if you need cash out and family mart for late night sushi snacks haha. The hotel is 2 min walk from Jimbocho station- we found it very easy to get around Tokyo from here. Imperial palace is also within walking distance.The staff are very friendly and helpful- they are also very fluent in english. They helped me find vegetarian restaurants within the area (There is a vegan cafe/restaurant 5 minutes away which was amazing!) as well as directions to places and helped me when booking my bus to Narita airport. The only con i can think of is that other travelers can be quite loud- which isn't the hotels fault- and the doors slam shut very loudly because they are heavy so i was woken up a lot by this. Just bring your own ear plugs for your stay.

The staff is very helpful and friendly. The food is good too and in the four days we were there they organized a party for all guests and a sake tasting evening. Great opportunaties to meet fellow travelers. The location is very close to the subway station. Our room was very, very small. But we requested a room near the toilet and we got it.

Clean, really efficient staff and great location. On top of it, they sell the 1, 2 or 3 day subway pass for overseas people!! They can help you 24/7 in anything you need. Facilities were also good I just missed the possibility on going up through stairs :) Can't say anything but "awesome place"!

I really enjoyed my stay at this hostel. It was clean and the facilities are excellent, the cafe/lobby area is open 24 hours and the staff are really helpful. It is right near a subway station which makes it easily accessible to pretty much everywhere in Tokyo. They held a party whilst I was there which was great to meet Japanese and international people. The only slightly annoying thing is that there is no self catering here which, for a solo traveller on a budget, would have been helpful.

A great place to stay I paid extra for a room as travelling alone and didn't want the hassle of storing luggag everyday. The staff are all very friendly and helpful, eveywhere is clean and there is a 24hr cafe so no need to worry about eating if your body clock is. Little or a lot out of sink. There also facilities to wash your clothes, a vending machine outside with a range of reasonably priced drinks, and a simple breakfast in the morning. Would definitely book again

When i visited they were very understanding, i had issues with my flight they manage to hold my room, the room rates are very reasonable and cheap :)But the rates are sooooo reasoable, plus its staff speaks english

I have stayed 5 days at this hotel with my family. I booked famliy room for 4 persons but we have 5 beds ;) Hotel is in good location, less than 5 mins walk from Jimbocho station. There were several convenience stores around the hotel. Breakfasts were good enough for the price, toasts and coffee. Staffs were energetic and helpful.

The quality of this place is rather a hostel for me. If I booked this place knowing as a hostel, I would have been quite happy about this place. Expecting a hotel, a little let down especially because I didn't have an ensuite bathroom/shower (I let my boyfriend book this place, so it was also my fault for not being aware of this place's facility). The room was really small, which is understandable for Tokyo, but when I opened the door, every time, the door touched the bed frame. I wouldn't mind staying here again because I could walk to Tokyo dome, the subway station is near and people were nice. I just know now what to expect.

Sakura hotel jimbocho was a genuinely pleasant experience for me. The atmosphere was great, the staff were always willing to help etc. The common area has an indoor and outdoor section. The outdoor area faces the tiny alley way street where people would be walking by and sometimes cars would go through. Grabbing a cold drink whilst sitting there facing the street and checking emails was enjoyable. The rooms are nice, don't expect much if you are on a budget like me. I stayed at a 6 bedroom dorm, and was later moved to the 4 bedroom dorm upstairs. Pick the upstairs dorm if you can, the baths and toilets are much nicer there. And you won't have to deal with weird bugs in the shower area as that is what I experienced in the basement. I'll definitely book with them again. Jimbocho is a quiet, safe and convenient area. Subway was 3 minutes away, and from there you can take the subway to any major areas of Tokyo.

I was on a budget so this place was perfect. My room was clean and so were the facilities. I was on the first floor - just around the corner from the indoor cafe area - so you might find the noise a bit inconvenient, but I was pretty tired by the end of the day so I slept great. Location is good - short walk from two different subway lines.I agree with previous posts about this place - great for the price - but please invest in better pillows as they are pretty hard! Aside from that, worth it.Friendly, relaxed staff also. Thanks!

It was the most expensive stay and the worst stay I had in a month travel in Japan. The hotel has terrible WiFi in the rooms. Only in the lounge is it acceptable. The location is not ideal, since it is more a metropolitain area of Tokyo. Several big parks and tokyo dome however are easy to access from here. The hotel also had the smart idea to build guest rooms right next to the 24 hour lounge area and then complain about being too loud. Dryer was terrible as it made the clothes more wet then dry. For the amount of money u can find better places to stay in Tokyo.

I'm smiling just thinking about this place. The room was small but the entire experience was endlessly fun! I was backpacking throughout Asia with my best friend and this was our last destination. We shared the semi-double room and it was SO fun to have this experience! The hotel gives you awesome robes to lounge about in which was great. And perhaps the biggest pro, it is SUPER clean!That being said, I've never been to a city quite like Tokyo. It really is irrelevant where you stay because the city is entirely safe and the metro is ridiculously efficient. We chose Jimbocho for its proximity to the palace. But on our other days of sightseeing, the night ended with us taking a short metro ride back to Jimbocho to crash at the hotel. In this respect, you could really stay anywhere in the city. So don't feel tied down to one area! Just look for the hotel that excites you the most because it's so easy to get around! I don't have an idea for the prices in other parts of the city but we were beyond satisfied with Sakura. Sakura Hotel Jimbocho is easy, clean, and fun! There were lots of other travelers; it reminded me of the nicest hostels I have stayed in in Europe. Really fun, communal vibe! We had the cheapest room option but there were full on businessmen here too so I'm sure the more expensive rooms are lovely too! The hotel staff was phenomenally helpful in all respects. Enjoy Tokyo! One of the coolest cities ever!

We went to Sakura hotel in jimbocho and it was really different from other hotels I've been to - the room is very small, it's slightly larger than a big car (or two) the toilet and shower is outside the room as well as the sink. I do believe it's a great place to stay for the price and the location - it's very close to the A1 and lots of convenience stores. The Wi-Fi is great and the food is also quite good.

It's located very close to the metro, convenience stores, and the city centre. The staff speaks English very well. The services are very good. Wi-Fi is usually very good but sometimes a bit slow or spotty. The showers aren't very big, but they do quite nicely.

My husband, 24-year old daughter and I stayed here in February of 2015. We stayed in a room for four having paid for the entire room. Meals were served downstairs, including a free simple breakfast. Staff was pleasant and friendly. I only had to wait once for a shower in our three nights there and then for only a few minutes. There was free wifi although it sometimes came and went. And the price was incredibly low! It was close to the subway station as well with a convenience store nearby for any forgotten essentials. We would definitely stay here again.

Sakura Hotel was very close to Jimbocho station and easy to find. It's in a very lovely neighbourhood surrounded by bookstores and close to Tokyo Imperial Palace. The staff are very friendly and organise get together events which makes it a great place to meet other fellow travellers or locals. I was in a single room which was okay for one person. The room was clean and the shared toilets and showers were equally clean. I would say it's a very good value for money. I would go again!

Really enjoyed my short stay at the property, which was near a very pleasant park. Neighbourhood is quiet, and hotel is functional, clean and pleasant, with most travellers keeping themselves to themselves. An hour to the airport via local trains. Breakfast was also pleasant enough. Stronger internet in the rooms would be welcome.

Last year for our honeymoon, my husband and I went to Tokyo and traveled across the US. Not only did we completely fall in love with Tokyo BUT we fell in love with the Sakura Hotel in Jimbocho and the whole district. The Jimbocho area is known for its second hand books and is such a beautiful quiet area while also being super vibrant and fun. We stayed in a semi-double room and it was more than enough for us. I've seen a lot of reviews saying how small their room was but I think people need to understand that this is part of the Tokyo experience and unless you have some serious money, all rooms you stay in will be small. You don't travel to another country to spend much time in your room anyway! The workers here were so nice and welcoming, allowing us to leave our bags before check in time while we wandered around. The breakfast was extensive and delicious, we met a lot of other people and many other Aussies. The 24hr Cafe and Front Desk is one of the best things about it. We could come and go at any time during the night and come back to welcoming smiling faces and yummy food and coffee. As soon as we left Tokyo we started planning our trip back and we really believe we owe a lot of that to the Sakura Hotel as it made a new city feel like home for us. Will definitely come back!
user_name:
Darcy H
Mount Gambier, South Australia, Australia

review_body: The staff were great, really helpful, always had time for you, to answer questions and show you how to get places on the map and organize a shuttle at another hotel. The toilets and showers were clean. it was quite. breakfast did the job, it was small downstairs for eating and no common room but you learn to deal and your there for japan not the hostel. my only complaint was the pillows are bit to hard for me but other then that, all good. close to everything, restaurants and train station.

First, I have to say, it is like a hotel (with resident sharing the facility) more than backpacker. So, adjust your expectation first, it is a place to stay more than a place to make friends in common area. They do have a common area, but not that kind of atmosphere, I am fine with it since I would rather have a rest after a long day shoppingEasy access to most of the tourist placerecommend you to buy the 1 day metro pass (it's cheaper if you can buy it from airport)Good:(1) just opposite to the metro station(2) Lift is available (some backpacker does not have, ask first)(3) Provide optional All-you-can eat breakfast at less than 400 yen. (4) Free Wifi, pillow, towel, blanket is provided(5) 24 hr reception(6) public computer is providedBad:Nil, at this momentHints:(1) nearest statation is Z07 (Suidobashi Jimbocho), get off at A9 exit instead of A6 as suggested by the hotel. Because, only A9 has lift provided in the metro station. when you get out from A9, cross the traffic light to the opposide to the road and start walking from your right hand side. after 100m, you will see the police counter, turn left to the street and keep walking until you see Sakura Hotel(2) If you did not turn at the police counter but keep walking, you will see a cosmetic shop. The price of this cosmetic shop is cheaper than those in Shibuya Z01, when both not provide tax free price.

My boyfriend and I stayed in a 'semi-double' room at the Sakura and found it perfect for our 1st night on Tokyo: a great place to arrive, check in with ease, crash out for an hour to stave off jet-lag, chug down a coffee in the café and head out to see Tokyo. Well connected and v easy to get to from Narita, easy to find from the subway. V friendly staff and nice basic rooms for a short and not-too-pricey stopover. Thumbs up!

The hotel had a friendly atmosphere from the start. It's handily located just around the corner from Jimbocho subway station and the lobby is small but serves drinks and snacks and staff are friendly. The whole place was spotlessly clean, rooms cleaned each day and clean yukatas and slippers in the rooms. Showers were shared but always clean and plenty for the amount of rooms so it worked very well. Highly recommended for a budget option.

i booked the hotel really late and Jimbocho was the only one that approved most of my days in Japan, i went to my friends for a few nights between the dates they gave me...it was really easy to find from the train station! i was really surprised how easy it was! a great bonus:)the price is really nice and the place is clean and pleasant, the staff helped me anytime and i felt secure.it was a bit far from Shibuya but nothing to be troubled over (15 min by train).i took the single small room which was enough for me and my things! (and i was shopping like crazy!)even thought the bathroom and shower were shared, it was clean,nice and almost always empty when i needed it !!and of course a great Wifi connection!!totally worth my money and more! might stay there again next time :)

Apart from the size of the room (which could say that it's normal Tokyo standard), and the internet connection inside my (private) room, this place is very good. Sometimes there were other residents that didn't care much about others and were very loud after midnight. The staffs were friendly. The cafe on first floor was great. The atmosphere there was so relaxed. It's a good place to drop by after a long day. Food was good. For breakfast, I didn't have the soupso I have no comment about that. The bread and coffee (or tea) were good.The location was quite good! (if you don't have a huge luggage) If you have a big luggage and you don't have enough strength to lift it up the stairs, I would recommend taxi. It might cost you a bit but you can save energy for your trip! The hotel is 2 mins (for me) to the metro station. From this station you can reach Shinjuku and Shibuya without changing the line. However, if you want to take JR train, then it's a little bit hard to get there. The shower was good. I would recommend taking a shower earlier than others. (It get a Iittle dirtier after time) I hope this helps! And sorry for my poor english :( Enjoy your trip in Tokyo!

This is a budget hotel, so the review is relative to the price compared to neighboring hotels. If you are looking for a clean, comfortable, convenient, but cheap place, then the Sakura is fine. The staff were very helpful, and everything was clean, but cramped. If you are over 188 cm, then you might bump your head in the shower stall, and the comforter will be too short too. Breakfast was white bread and tea/coffee and soup, but you could pay more and get eggs - I ate out. There are two PCs you can use in the restaurant. The hotel is in the center of the city and very easy to get anywhere by subway. You can easily walk to the emperor's palace, national museum of modern art, Tokyo dome, or Yasukuni shrine to name a few. Jimbocho is a major subway station on three lines. It is very easy to get from Haneda (domestic or international terminals) to the Sakura with only one change at Mita (detailed on the hotel web site). If you are new to Tokyo, please note that there are two subway providers: Toei with four lines, and Tokyo Metro with nine lines. You can get a one or two day pass for just the Toei or pay more for both lines. Jimbocho has lines from both providers, but I only needed the Toei (610 yen Haneda to Jimbocho, or 800 yen for a one day pass). You can get handouts in English explaining ticket details before the ticket gates to enter the subway (Keikyu line - express) or ask at an information island.

I stayed here for a week over the new years period in a dorm room. It was pretty cramped and the decor itself didn't feel too appealing but the bed itself was more comfortable than it looks, curtains are provided so you can have privacy. These things might not be appealing to some but since I was just interested in a place to sleep for the night, they more than exceeded my expectations.One negative point about the room would be the lack of power points but it's not a big issue for me.The place itself is located in a quieter side street so for the first time, you may have a bit of trouble especially without proper directions but the location itself is perfect for sightseeing. The closest station is jimbocho, a short walk away and from there, getting to any of the major sightseeing locations is a breeze. The hotel has a very nice cafe where you can just relax after a day of sightseeing and there's 2 computers available for guests to use without charge. The staff are wonderful and really helpful which makes the place worth it. Location wise and price wise, I say it's worth every penny. They provide free wi-fi which was nice. The connection could get a bit unstable but I didn't find it a big deal.This is not a traditional hotel though so don't expect the luxuries associated but for a budget traveler who needs a place to sleep, I highly recommend this place. Will definitely come back if I get the chance to.

We stayed here on our trip through Japan and I couldn't have asked for a better place. The staff was helpful and friendly, tasty/cheap foods available (most of it cooked in the cafe downstairs), clean rooms, social area, safe/quiet neighborhood and at a good price. It's everything you want when you're backpacking. Obviously the rooms are not large...but you are at a hostel AND in Tokyo, so you shouldn't be expecting that anyways. The cafe downstairs has a variety of different meals and everything I had there tasted pretty good. Will definitely be coming back.

This is principally a backpacker/budget hotel, so don't expect large rooms, extensive breakfasts, or private showers. HOwever, the rooms are clean, the beds are comfortable, and the showers are hot. It's close to Akihabara and other sights of Japan so you probably won't be staying in your room a lot anyway.Breakfast is tea and toast - the toasters need replacing as they are SLOW, but the food is easy and the coffee/tea plentiful. Close to the train station and book stores, and easy walking to restaurants. We tried the pizza place up the road (as you do in Japan) which was very nice. Also tried the boutique beer place nearby - not recommended.The staff are friendly, you can store your bags in reception if need be, and really if you're there sightseeing or shopping it's really all you need.

I choose this hotel for one week stay, the staff was incredible, very friendly and helpful. The rooms and bathroom are properly cleaned and the blanket was very comfortable. The hotel has a smoking terrace.There is also a subway station 5 minutes walking from the hotel and the area is very safe and quiet.

I was there from Sunday to Thursday in November 2013 for a conference. The price seemed to be reasonable for Tokyo, although in the beginning of the week I could have stayed at a nice hotel nearby for the same price. They have a nice lounge in the lobby where you can sit, order drinks and food, or sit and work. The rooms are tiny, as expected, and despite the no-smoking policy, smoke came in from the street. My room also faced the wall of the building next door. The staff was very accommodating and moved me to a new room at my request. I can't say much about how accessible the rest of the city is from there since I was focused on the conference, but the neighborhood is clean and quiet.

The Hotel itself was convenient and great for the price tag. Close to 2 train stations the Metro and JR Line ones, peaceful area. Food is pretty standard there, but the staff is very nice, they helped me solve my sim card problem without hesitation, very great staff also held a present for a friend for me to pick up. I don't mind the share bathroom system, because it doesn't really bother anyone, you can't hear anyone taking a shower or toilet. But However rooms aren't sound proof, and I was able to hear some of my neighbors. I stayed in a single bed room, every time I came back to it, it was always clean. The hotel itself is always clean. Good recommendation for the budget traveler. And they speak multiple languages.

This hostel is located right by the Jimbocho subway station, and about a 10-15 min walk from a JR rail line. It is also a 10 min walk from the Imperial Palace. The staff is friendly, and as a pleasant surprise can speak english rather fluently. The room was clean but I wouldn't say there was anything outstanding or memorable about it. A great place to stop over if you are in tokyo for a few days.

I stayed at Sakura Hotel Jimbocho for 2 nights. I think that location of this hostel is very good since it's far from Jimbocho train station exit (A1 exit) about 3-5 minutes by walk and Jimbocho station have multiple of railway line across it so you can travel to many interesting places such as Shinjuku Shibuya, Akibahara by start from here and it has the luggage delivery service company (Kuroneko) just behind hotelA room: I stayed at male dorm room at basement level. I slept at upper bed and that's a problem because the ladder that I use to get up to bed is very unstable that I think that big man will have problem to use it. Furthermore plugsocket is available only at lower bed so if you stayed at upper bed you should take power strip with youBut the most impressive thing about this hostel is staff. They can speak English quite well and don't hesitate to help you in many way; suggestion of restaurant, interesting place and how to get there, luggage delivery service and they help you with a smile. It's make me want to use this hotel againConclusion: this hostel is suitable for backpacker who want to travel around Tokyo, don't serious about quality of bedroom and no need to use notebook or you should take power strip with you

Went to this Hotel on 2013. Ambience and environment was really warm and gave off a "house" feel. Reception staff was really friendly and even cracked some jokes with us! We took 3-man rooms. 1 Double deck and 1 flat bed. They were super comfy! Toilets were clean, shower rooms are always well stocked with shampoo and body foam.Best thing? This hostel is close to ; 7-11 , convenience store, Akihabara and the Train station. What else do you need to consider? PRICE WAS AFFORDABLE TOO!

You could stay anywhere and as long as they got a bed and bathroom facilities, you're good to go. However, what made this hotel stand out so much for me was the staff. They went out of their way to make me feel at home and provided wonderful and easy to follow directions and planning for the sites, attractions, and events that I wanted to do. To show genuine interest and appreciation shows a lot about the staff or person. I feel like I've made long term friends here in Japan. Thank you Peter and Ayaka for showing me there's more to Japan than just a bed and some sites.

I was in Tokyo in March for work, and was allowed to choose my own hotel.I picked Sakura Hotel mainly because my own company shares the same name (Sakura)-it was rather amusing at the time.The location is great- right in Kanda-Jinbocho (aka book town).KJ itself is nothing to shout about, unless you're interested in scholarly books.There's a subway station not too far away too, and Akihabara is a short ride away- heck you can walk there. Yasukuni is just up the road, and I walked to the palace and Ginza as well.The hotel itself can be somewhat hard to find though, if you don't have detailed instructions or GPS available.I got myself a private room with a single bed- it was small but functional. Aircon, TV, bed, clothes hangers, enough space to dump my bags. With curtains closed and the lights off, the room is pitch black- I forgot to set my alarm, and woke up the next day by the sound of someone calling 'room cleaning'. For a moment I thought they must be crazy to clean occupied rooms so early in the morning, but when I looked at the time, it was already close to noon. It's THAT dark in there.I don't have any complaints- overall it was quite a good stay. The carpeted floor in the room was a little damp- I have no idea why, but it didn't bother me too much.Love the honey toast breakfast too, though I wonder why they labeled it as 'ladies' favorite' or something like that. Guys like sweet stuff too!

5 to 7 minutes walk from the hotel to Jimbocho station on 3 of the Tokyo subway lines. Able to travel easily to most of the tourist attractions in Tokyo. Breakfast is at a reasonable price (coffee, toast, eggs etc) A few 24hr convenient stores located nearby, in case you need to buy groceries or other necessities.

It's recommended.. the location is strategic near MRT station and there are bunch of nice cafes & restos around to grab some lunch or dinner. There are traditional Japanese resto, as well as western. And the reception are nice with good english too ^^

I paid for a private room so it wasnt really CHEAP CHEAP like a dorm but was still good :)VERY CONVENIENT LOCATION. I was there for a concert at Nippon Budoukan and it was within walking distance. Not to mention it was just a short less than 5 minutes walk to the train station and there are so many family marts around the hostel. Whats more is that the hostel has a 24hr cafe/restaurant so i can head down to buy a proper meal when im really hungry.Might be a little scary to walk back to the hostel at night because the streets can be really quiet. What's more i was traveling solo but hey, it's japan i dont really worry that much.BUT, the cleanliness in the room is not THAT good. The stains on the walls can be really obvious.. I'm just glad there are no stains on the sheets :)However, right beside my bed was a huge cabinet which couldnt be opened cos my bed was blocked but the cabinet wasnt locked either! I was scaring myself the entire period thinking what is it lol.Toilets/shower rooms available on every level so that's really convenient! I will definitely try out other sakura hotels :)

It was a great experience to stay in the Sakura house. The Staff was much friendly. The Sakura hostel room in which i stayed was spacious. The bathroom was clean and tidy. The neighbors were friendly and cooperative. The place was near a park and few restaurants. Stores, Train station and shopping mall was all within the walking distance.

I was there for 4 nights and I enjoyed myself a lot. The price is considered cheap (slightly more expensive that hostels in Asakusa) since it is located closer the Shibuya. It was very comfortable and the shared toilet is very clean. There is a cafe that allows you to mingle with other tourists or even locals who frequently patronize the cafe.The hostel is a few minutes walk from Jimbocho station(during subway to Shibuya) or a 10 minutes walk from Suidobashi JR station(convenient for those who holds a JR pass)I met Peter-san and Riko-san, who were sitting at the front desk and they are very kind and helpful people. They will also initiate conversation with you. They are multilingual and can speak English, Japanese, Spanish and Mandarin (some German as well if I am not wrong).I will definitely stay there again if I go back to Tokyo.

The ever busy Sakura Hotel is a great location to explore Tokyo from. We spent a superb two nights here in a fairly spacious (by all accounts) double room. Comfy bunk-beds meant good quality sleep and the shared wash facilities were fine and clean. Lots of information to hand and really friendly staff who worked tirelessly to answer guests questions (fired from all directions constantly). Considering how busy it is it is very well managed and maintained. We were on a round-the-world trip (tight budget) and as a city centre stay-over Sakura definitely ranks near the top (and hundreds of leagues above the next place in Delhi!).

Stayed at Sakura Hotel Jimbocho for almost 2 weeks. Our room was very small, even for two very slim persons it felt crowded sometimes. But I think it's fine, the smallness of the room didn't really bother me most of the time. Even though it's a cheap hotel, it's very clean. We got up pretty late everyday and met the nice cleaning ladies around 11am+. They do a great job cleaning the room every day. Everyday you get new yutakas and small towelettes. Since everyone on the same floor (there are 5 different floors) share bathroom and shower room, the dirtyness really depend on what kind of people you stay with at the moment. The first few days everyone kept the teethbrushing area very clean, but a few days later some american teenagers came and well... there were hair and make up remains in the sink. Also I discovered that there's no sound isolation really, most people try to keep a soft volume in their rooms but these teenagers didn't and you could hear everything they did. Since our room were just outside the sinks and were you brush your teeth, every night I could hear peoples teethbrushing routine, the spitting, gurgling and all. :( But I'm still satisfied with my stay at Sakura and would probably recommend it to people who wants a cheap, clean room. The staff were pretty nice and spoke good english.To travellers planning to stay here my tip is to NEVER eat at the hotel, it's expensive 500+yen for a bad meal, you can get 3-400yen much better meals at restaurants close to the A1 exit from Jimbocho st. There are plenty of nice bookstores around the area, take a look inside - some of them have english books and old comics that might be worth a lot.Happy stay! :)

I was having a few days in tokyo and decided to take this hotel mostly because of the price. It is sort of hotel/hostel thing, where rooms are pretty small but I guess that's the thing in Japan anyway :-) Good location, pretty close to metro and to cigarette vending machine :-) Staff was really nice and friendly. Good place for not too spend a lot of money and still being close to transportation.

Spent three nights in the girls dormitory. The room is in a basement, has no natural light or ventilation, and adjoins the ho(s)tel's boiler and wash room. It is incredibly loud 24/7. Even by Japanese hostel standards the room is cramped (and not particularly clean). Avoid.

I was mainly concerned about service quality and that was exactly what I received at the Sakura Hotel in Jimbocho. I encountered a couple of stressful problems while I was traveling in Japan (my own mistakes) but the staff really helped me out and made sure if if everything was fine at the end. I had a lot of trouble trying to make an international call which took me hours to figure out, but without me asking the staff kindly helped me out from the beginning and made the situation feel much less stressful. In the future I plan on coming back here!

Clean and compact, the rooms are tiny but deliver everything you need - so long as you don't need to swing a cat. The staff were very helpful, giving excellent advice on things like negotiating the Tokyo subway system. So long as you don't mind the toilet and shower down the hall (actually 2 paces from our room) this is a great place for travellers on a budget.

I had a great time here. I traveled alone to Japan from the US as a 22 year old girl and was so happy I was directed to this hostel. The staff was so friendly and I knew at any time of day or night I would be greeted my smiling faces and could buy a hot meat and coffee. The other people I stay with in the dorms we SO friendly. It a cozy home in a big city. The beds were comfortable and had screens so your bed could be pitch black even though all the lights were on. Location was PERFECT. lovvved it here, would suggest to anyone on an adventure

Tess H
Monteverde Cloud Forest Reserve, Costa Rica

review_body: Compared to my bad experience at Hotel Istana Ratu in Jakarta where my nephew lost his money in his backpack inside our room, Sakura Jimbocho hotel's staff are honest and helpful. I left my money and credit card with the receptionist who just placed them on the rack (not safety box) in a room right next to the reception. Everything was intact when I got them back. The hotel is centrally located, clean and affordable. I highly recommend this hotel to travellers travelling alone lilke me or travelling with family/friends.

If you want a good sleep, don't choose the male dorm. There is one person making long stay who keeps on coughing at night, i don't even get one night of good sleep. Also the staff couldn't help me with the problem, they only asked me to add money to change to single room, which is too costly for me.

Hotel is situated in a great location and metro is just around the corner. Staff was very friendly. Rooms are small, but everything is clean and well organized. Sakura Jimbocho made it easy to expierence Tokyo on a budget.

Good hotel, simple but very clean. Thay give you what you need, helpful staff, clean room, good furniture (simple but good), good room service and it's near to underground! If you jump in tokyo, go there!!

Sakura is a hostel which has small private rooms and all other facilities are shared.The rooms are tiny by non Tokyo standards and probably the smallest room we have stayed in anywhere, however Tokyo hotel rooms are famously small. The staff are friendly with decent English and the place is clean and comfortable. The walls are a little thin and some of the other guests could be heard talking throughout the night, although this is not uncommon in a hostel type environment. We paid about $70 AUD / night which include white bread, vegetable soup and tea / coffee (the breakfast).The location is great if you are a fitness champion - only 3 mins jog to the Imperial palace garden running track, which is a pleasant 5km loop. It is definitely a case of you get what you pay for here so if you are looking for a budget option this place is fine.

The hotel was easy to find, and on arrival we was greeted by friendly staff who spoke great English. The hotel has a kind of hostel feel to it and had a really nice friendly atmosphere. Our room was small, which you would expect, but was completely fine with us as we only used it for sleeping anyway. We had no problem with noise from inside or outside of the hotel, and on hot days it was always nice to come back to a chilled room with A/C. The toilets, showers and sinks are communal but we never had to wait to use any of them, and they were all clean. The location was perfect for us, with Jimbocho station 2 minutes walk away. There were plenty of shops nearby for us to get any drinks or snacks too. We're already planning on staying here again for our next trip to Tokyo. Would 100% recommend this place.

Hello!!If you are thinking about to chose a hotel in Japan... Think calm twice! You can spend a lot of money in a business hotel and get bored or... you may join to Sakura Jimbocho Hotel! You will have taken the best place to stay in Tokyo! Open 24h, clean rooms, comfortable beds, events... etcAs a guest in Sakura Jimbocho Hostel, It was a great experience to meet the staff who was very kind and helpful. It's been my 3rd time in Tokyo and I found my second home; not only located in a quiet neighbourhood but full of life. There are Convienence Stores such as 7 Eleven and Family Mart, which allow you to withdraw money without charge, buy anything you need (open 24h) and many many restaurants around the hotel which will be closed around 20 or 21 pmI was using a JR Pass and if you go to "Suidobashi" station in the Sobu Line (yellow colour) You have to walk 800m but you also have Jimbocho (Metro Tokyo) at 5 minutes by walkingIf my words have not convinced you... I just wish you good luck! I may miss other places in Tokyo, but I will go back to Sakura Jimbocho Hotel.Enjoy your trip to Japan!

I stayed at the Sakura Hotel in Jimbocho as a student for 4 weeks in May 2013. The rooms are fairly small for people with a month of clothing and whatnot, although they'd be fine if you were only packed for a week or so. No personal bathrooms or showers, although the public bathrooms/showers for people on each floor are fairly good. The front desk is friendly and the location is very good.

We stayed here for 4 days last week with a group of 14 people! I email the hotel management to set up rooms for 14 people and they give us dormitory room. although its a dormitory room, but the space are something! the staff can speak fluent english especially the night shift. the location also strategic, located 5 mins walk from train station and 2 station away from akihabara. and the imperial palace is in a walking distance. the price is very reasonable considering the fact that this is Tokyo. this is my first time in Tokyo so I dont know any hotel with good location other that Sakura Hotel Jimbocho. I will definately will visit this hotel next time!

The hotel/hostel is situated within walking distance from the Imperial Palace and other great sightseeing locations. Travelling to and from the hotel is remarkably easy and there are several train stations within a couple of miles. One station is probably 20 metres away, so it's never too difficult to get there and back. I did find it a bit confusing the first time I arrived, but it's very easy to navigate after that first time.As for the hotel, the staff are friendly and are always willing to try to help you. There is a small café situated within the hotel and food is served 24/7; as are a number of worldwide drinks; Beers, in particular. There is an outside smoking area. It's a bit of a negative point as well as it's right next to the entrance. If you're not a smoker, it could be irritating.If you're a tech-head like myself, wireless is available on the lower floors and it's quite stable. There's also an public computer that offers internet access, for a price. Akihabara is about 30 minutes away on foot as well.Rooms are clean and comfortable. Although the views from the room aren't spectacular, for the price, it wasn't a problem. I was there to sightsee rather than stare out of a hotel window anyway. The television works and the refrigerators are quiet, which is a nice touch. The room I was saying in had bunk beds. They were a little squeaky. I think that's my only real gripe with the room I was in. I have stayed in other rooms and this hasn't been the case with those.The shower and washing facilities are shared, however are usually kept very clean. I personally don't mind that so much as I've met a few interesting people whilst washing my face/brushing my teeth. It's not everyone's cup of tea, of course. The hotel's usual clientèle seem to be around the 20-30 year old range. There were a few older people, however. Although the age range staying there is quite young, they usually respect other guests.I recommend staying here to anyone who is either backpacking or anyone who sightseeing with friends. I can't comment on the couple of family side of the hotel, of course.On an additional note, the staff speak various languages. I know that one member of staff was able to speak four other languages besides Japanese.

Always our choice in Tokyo. Wonderful melting pot of travellers, close to metro subway and reasonably priced. Don't expect luxury, but thats not why we travel, right? Happy to recommend and would return in a heart beat

I went to Tokyo last year on a solo semi-business trip. I choose this hotel because of the location: dead central! I went nearly everywhere in Tokyo for roughly the same distance and price, while can still make it back catching the last train available, and have enough sleep for tomorrow's work! Ideal for me who likes to get lost alone in the concrete jungle. And yes, I stayed here also because it is budget friendly. :DStayed here for about 10 days in a single private room, not much of space but I really don't mind. Facilities are OK and rooms are kept clean.Areas around it are rather quiet, but if you want some extra noise just hop in to the train or walk to see the area around it, there are a little bit of crowd just a few stations away, or some in walking distance!Staff were super friendly, all the way from reservation until I checked out, everything was a pleasant memorable stay.In my actual planned itinerary, I was to move to Asakusa for my last 3 days in Tokyo, but I canceled it an choose to stay here instead, because it felt warm, cozy and homy, and easy to get to almost everywhere! :D

Jakarta, Jakarta Raya, Indonesia

review_body: We stayed at sakura for 3 nights in late July. Overall it is really good value for the location. Staff are extremely friendly and helpful and it has a quiet relaxed vibe. The rooms are small and could do with redecorating and the breakfast is minimal, but overall we were very pleased considering the price. Location just two stops from Tokyo is fantastic , especially after a long flight.

Pretty and helpful staff at the FD, they helped me soo much! They showed me around, recommended me restaurants and helped me to store my luggages for few days without any fee. I took a twin room by myself soo it was spacious and private. Internet was fast and free. Wish that I could stay longer but the hotel was fully booked already. Thanks and matane!

Pros: hotel is pretty easy to reach by subway from Tokyo Station, animated and central location close to lots of subway stations, staff is friendly and speaks perfect English, rooms and facilities are clean, wi-fi access, breakfast and bar available, budget friendly compared to Tokyo standards.Cons: the hotel made a mistake in our reservation and gave us a 2-people-bedroom instead of a 3-people one. They apologized and gave us an extra mattress, but our room was still pretty crowded. Just make sure they got the right reservation by sending them an e-mail before you go. ;)

Stayed in March 2009.RoomIf you want hostel prices at a good location, with the privacy of having your own room, the twin room is great. It had a double bunker, a one-seater sofa, TV, heater, and just enough leg room to lay out 2 suitcases. It ain't big, doesn't have its own washroom, but it is cheap comparing to other Tokyo accommodation for just SGD60 per person per night (prices may be higher now).Shared amenitiesWashroom (read: basins, toilets, shower area) are all located in the center of each floor. All rooms surround the amenities area in the middle. To me, that's a really smart design as the toilet is literally outside your room, not like other hostels I know that you have to walk to the corner of each floor to reach the toilet. The washroom area is extremely functional and clean at all times.LocationMany who stayed appreciate the central location, but not the lack of activity around the area. First, you have to know that Jimbocho is considered a business district. Comparing to Singapore, it is like staying in the quiet part of Tanjong Pagar. It is extremely central, but come nightfall, it is definitely not a place near any entertainment nor food nor services. It is not easy to find it at night too. It is real quiet at night, so if you prefer somewhere with a more happening night life, pls choose Shinjuku area. Yet, no worries about getting hungry because just a few minutes walk away, just beside Red Cross House, there is a supermarket where you can get cheap meals/ drinks/ fresh fruits. A convenient store is nearby too. Another interesting observation - because it is in the business district, it gets terribly crowded when you are at the Jimbocho station in the morning rush hour. It was kind of fun to witness how the Tokyo work-goers are walking in extremely fast and yet orderly fashion.StaffMany of the staff speak very good English, perhaps because many of them are travelers too! We spoke to a few staff and realized that in exchange for cheaper (or free) long term stay, they work as reception during some days. Quite a cool concept, if you are considering to do the same :) And since they are also travelers/explorers, they are very resourceful in places to go. Chat with them!Stay again?Considering its cleanliness and the the idea of staying in a hostel where you can meet many other young travelers of different nationalities, exchanging notes of where to go, it is definitely somewhere I would stay again. However, if you are a young couple or family who wants more privacy and more accessibility, I suggest trying their much newer outlet - Sakura Shinjuku.
