review_body: It was a great stay in this place, friendly staff, clean rooms and perfec location, right in the middle of Tokyo, allowed us to walk arounf easily and no far of the Subway station. Without a doubt, I recommend it if you are considering to visit Japan

I recently stayed at Sakura for 4 days. I stayed at the dormitory in the basement. Here are the Pros and Cons:PROS:1. Very affordable (still expensive but you can't find anything cheaper than that in Tokyo)2. Excellent location - just a five min walk from Jimbocho station. Jimbocho station lies on Shinjuku line (of coursen that goes to Shinjuku),Hanzomon line (Goes to Shibuya) and Mita Line.3. 24 hour cafe and bar4. Good security - your access card is changed everyday. That is a very good way of ensuring security for shared accomodation like dorms.5. Staff is super fluent in English - at times I wonder if they are Japanese!!6. Book swap - you can swap your books for the ones in their library. I did a swap too. It is a win-win for everybody. 7. Curtains on dorm beds - I didn't realize these curtains could help so much. Your sleep is not affected by people switching on lights, using cellphones etc. Of course, that doesn't stop the noise of slamming doors!!CONS:1. Ventilation is bad in basement dorm - if you plan to stay in the hotel during the day, then I would not recommend the basement dorms. However, if you are just going to use it for night's sleep like I did, then you are perfectly fine. Even if one of the guests has a contagious infection, you are affected.

Nothing wrong with this hostel, it was my first in Japan. I was underwhelmed at the time and found during my month in Japan there WERE much better backpacker places. I did not stay there again the two times I came back into the city. My title really sums it up. It has everything you would want, need, or expect from a hostel...it was just sleepy. There was a neat hipstery craft beer restaurant nearby, otherwise nothing else close as far as food. The area kinda shuts down with the bookshops. The area is central to everything else and walkable to Akihabara. Jimbocho Metro station 2 1/2 blocks away. Close to Tokyo station but awkwardly connected thru metro station. Wish I could give value and overall ratings of 3.5.

I stayed several nights here with a group of American college students. This place would not have been my choice if I had been traveling alone, with a family, or with other adults.First, a few of the pros. It's actually in a good location. The subway line is very close (less than 5 minutes on foot), and of course, that gets you anywhere you want to go in Tokyo. The Imperial Palace is an easy and pleasant 20-minute walk--quicker to walk than take public transportation There are shops and restaurants galore, including the used book district and the sporting-goods (think, REI-type stuff) district very close by. Above all, the price can't be beat considering that it's Tokyo. Hotels are expensive in Tokyo, and budget travelers don't have a lot of great options. The rooms also have AC and TV. The international staff is friendly and helpful, and a small cafe on the first floor provides a place to relax over coffee or get a not-so-good meal.But there were plenty of cons. This is not a hotel. It's a very basic, no-frills, rough-around-the-edges hostel. The rooms are small (but this is typical in Japan anyway, even in the nicest hotels, so really isn't unique). Some rooms have single beds, others have bunk beds. Showers, toilets, and sinks are all separate from the rooms and from one another, which means when you step outside your room, you're running into people brushing their teeth, etc. at the sinks. Everything looks and feels old and worn-out. The "breakfast" is instant soup and toast. When you have a city filled with world-class food, the cafe is definitely something to avoid. And if you're not interested in being surrounded by sometimes-loud 20-somethings, this isn't your place.There are better affordable places to stay in Tokyo.

Twice I travelled to Tokyo alone and really LOVE this location and the hotel and staff. The second time my daughter came with me. Located in a great neighborhood and very clean, it feels like a good home away from home. Heck I wish Tokyo was my home!

Japan is expensive, and I would expect to pay for what we got at Sakura. The staff were friendly, the bathrooms and the room were all very clean, and the ammenities (robe, bath towel, and free shampoo/body wash) were nice. The internet service is fast and good, and myself and my fellow vegan traveller loved that the 24 hour cafe had a soy latte on the menu! The room was small, but nice. We rented a private twin room, which we were also suprised had a couch that folded into a mattress. Very near to subway station. Best to take a cab from Tokyo station if you have a lot of luggage (about 14 USD) - switching from the airport line to the local line is no easy task!

Message bodyI rented a single private room here.This is a great location.It is close to the Imperial palace and surrounded by awesome book shops.The location can be a challenge to find from Tokyo Station if you are not familar with the subway lines.I liked the 24 hour cafe and the friendly staff.

This hotel has very much a hostel feel to it. The staff, the layout, the quality, all very hostelly. And that's no bad thing as long as you're aware of that in advance.All I was looking for was a place to sleep, and it sufficed. Tiny room, not ensuite. But it had a bed which was the only requirement.The location is just fine, but if you're visitng the most popular areas of Tokyo it's not quite on the doorstep and you could probably find a higher standard of room at similar distances to the likes of Shibuya etc. for not that much more money.On site 24 cafe/bar was quite nice. Very much marketed at the non-Japanese speaking traveller which may be useful for some too.Perhaps of most interest to backpackers who want a private room. Overall - functional. Nothing more.

The Sakura Hotel was recommended by a friend who has traveled in Japan a lot - i.e. every year for 20 years and he has stayed in hundreds of Tokyo hotels.I stayed here with 3 friends and the room was very small with 2 bunk beds (sleeping 4).That's it for the room other than a small table and TV - that we had to move to get our bags in.Toilet and shower and sink are all separate and positioned around the centre of the floor (all rooms open onto the corridor where they are.Downstairs is a cafe selling snacks and drinks, with free coffee. There's also a computer with Internet (can't recall if it costs $$).Overall, very friendly service - the reception guys couldn't do enough. Their English was good.The rooms were small and clean.The value was wonderful.If you're going to spend a lot of time in your room, then you'll be disappointed, but as a centrally located, close to subway hotel in Tokyo it's just fine. And, like I said, the value is terrific.My only complaint would be that the 3 other guys with me snored all night!I'd stay here again - just know the rooms are small, with the bathrooms outside the room servicing all the rooms on that floor (6 rooms each floor I think).

I recently went to Japan during the big Earthquake. I was staying at Sakura Hotel at the time. They were on top of everything. They had snacks and tea for the people staying there. The news as on they had flashlights ready. They answered all my questions. They were very helpful and friendly when I needed to call home and use the internet. Honestly they had the best staff of any Hotel I've stayed in. I've been around the world and they made my very short stay in Tokyo during that traumatic time even easier on me. It's not fancy but it is very friendly.

I stayed there for 3 nights and its good value for money. Close to the underground and jr station , stayed in a single room and the room is a bit crampy but the bed was great, and your out all day anyway. The area is really chilled compared to other parts of town and that`s why i decided to stay there, easy to get around and lots of restaurants near by.Staff very friendly and helpful , free wifi and in general very clean and nice. Im gonna stay here on my next visit as well.

We stayed one night only in this hotel and it was ok. The room are pretty basic but the fact that you have to get outside to get to the bathroom is a bit bad. The common area and the staff are really good and they are nice to meet other travelers. I'd recommend this hotel but warn the person not to expect anything else than a bed and a place to chat.

I booked in for 5 nights in my last week in Tokyo as I had no where to stay after leaving my apartment, I was just looking for a cheap place to stay and had been to one of there other hostels in 2007 and had a great time. click link below for review:http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUserReviews-g1066461-d644891-r14023156-Sakura_Hostel_Asakusa-Taito_Tokyo_Tokyo_Prefecture_Kanto.htmlI arrived a bit early and the guy behind the counter said I could not go in as my bed was not ready, this of course was fine as I was early. After about 30 minutes after the time I was supposed to be allowed in the room he told me the room was ready. After I entered my room I saw there was still someone sleeping in the bed, I went back to reception thinking that they must of given me the wrong room or something, turns out that it was the right room and they has not checked the room. He asked me to sit in the reception and wait while they sorted it out, to be fair he did sort things out quickly and took me to my room.On closer inspection of the room it was not very clean, I was surprised to hear this hotel won a cleanliness award in 2009! I canceled my reservation at the hotel and moved to a last min 5 star hotel deal I found on Rakuten for a similar kind of price. He did give me a refund for the next 4 nights but said he could not refund the 1st night so I was out of pocket by 4000 odd yen.I think its a real shame as they have a great location and space to run a really good hotel here. I hope they manage to improve it in the near future.Any questions just drop me a line

The Sakura Hotel Jimbocho; how dare they call themselves a hotel? It was definitely more like a hostel. The room was the tiniest room I've ever slept in, really not very nice when you arrive all jet-lagged and are too tired and sick to go out much. We didn't want to stay in the room, but we couldn't go outside either. Though it's close to the station and in a nice area, it's not that nice if you want to go sightseeing a lot as there isn't much very close to the hotel. If you want to stay in a Sakura hotel, I recommend Sakura Ikebukuro (they call themselves hostel, but I'd gladly give them the title hotel).The staff were nice and helpful, that is definitely a positive. But everything is just too tiny to be comfortable.

We stayed in Sakura Hotel for 7 nights and we'd definitely go back there.Best thing was the staff. The only bad thing is that, during mornings, the recepcionist has both to act as a recepcionist as well as a waiter. They should hire someone else because they looked preety overwhelmed by the amount of job and clearly it wasn't their fault. They just can't split. Owners, if you read me: hire some waitress for 4 hours! ;)Bed was very confortable. Room was small, but well... be honest: price is far under average so don't complain about its size. We had the room we asked for (high floor, double bed) and we had a very nice time there.Also, they have free wi-fi, which is a plus!Absolutely advisable, close to the subway (3-4 minutes walk) and to the JR line (10-15 minutes walk), nice restaurants around (Ikooya or something similar being the best one).I tell you: a night place to be if you're going to Tokyo!

We stayed here for 5 nights and enjoyed our stay. We stayed in a double room although it was really tiny. The bed took up most of the room though it was barely a double bed. With bags in the room it was really squishy and standing room only, however that was the only down side. They had a cleaning service every day so the room was spotless. Facilities were great, there were 4 bathrooms and toilets per floor and were rarely occupied so there was no wait for a shower. The cafe on the ground floor provided a good all you can eat continental breakfast for around $4 dollars. The communal lobby area had computers with internet, as well as free wi-fi. The area is not really central to everything but it is close to the Jimbocho subway station which is easy enough to find. I would deffinitely stay here again but would recommend getting a twin room if you are with others.

I've stayed here three times now and every expereience has been great. The staff is very helpful, friendly and multilingual. They've always handled my reservations without any problems and have been flexible for me. The location is great, walking distance to the subway. It's clean and convenient. I always manage to make friends here as it is popular with backpackers and English teachers.

Very good price/quality ratio. The rooms might be a little small but the location of the hotel (centre of Tokyo), the price and the discreet but efficient service makes this hotel one of the options for a low or mid budget stay in this city. the English speaking staff (which might be rare in japan) is extremely friendly and nice.

I had a private room for one night. I wouldn't have wanted to spend too much time in the room as it was tiny! But it was clean with a good size bed. The staff are very friendly and helpful and it is walking distance from the Imperial Palace Gardens. If you have a Japan Rail pass and want to save on getting metro tickets, you can get off at Suidobashi (I think its called) and walk to the hotel. Takes less than 10mins.

This hotel was located in the Jimbocho area, which was the bookshop district and 1-2 subway stations away from the central Tokyo station. The location was quite convenient and had plenty of eateries around and a supermarket on the way to the subway station.The rooms are small and felt like a dorm with our uncomfortable bunk beds even with our request for doubles room. The whole place reeks of cigarette smoke even though it is now smoke-free. Shower and sink facilities are all shared on each level and these were clean and well kept.There was no complimentary tea/coffee as you would expect in a hotel as the downstairs lounge/tv area is a 24 hour cafe. Internet is charged at 100 yen per 10 minutes.Staff are very helpful, speak English and are available 24 hours a day.

I decided on this hotel after much searching on the internet and realising that Tokyo is an expensive place. Once I accepted that, the rooms here are great. Small, but I only planned to sleep or sit in mine, so adequate for my purposes. Quiet, tidy, internet in the rooms is free (and WiFi in my case), snacks seem to be available all day, simple breakfast included (all of these things cost a packet inTokyo, so if the hotel provides them and you want them then it makes the room value even better). The location is also great. Tokyo is huge and unless you need to be in a specific area, this place is well located to get to anywhere by subway or rail, and is in easy walking distance of the Imperial Palace and you can stroll on to downtown.Given that Tokyo can be a bit of a culture shock, the true asset of this hotel is the staff. Even before I got on the plane I had been sent directions from Narita Airport to the hotel in excellent English. I reckoned I could have found it by myself, but it would have taken a lot longer - their directions led me there without delay.The squad at reception speak superb English and are amazingly helpful. I wanted to go to the Ghibli museum and it was going to be difficult as they only accept tickets bought and collected in advance and in Japan this has to be done on the internet and then collected from a vending machine in a specific chain of convenience shops. The vending machine system would be impossible to negotiate for a non-japanese speaker. Not only did the receptionist guy sort out the details on the internet, he then left the desk and walked with me to one of these stores near the hotel to sort out the vending machine for me. This was really beyond the call of duty and the main reason I am writing this review - I have never been moved to write a review of a hotel before, but these guys tipped the balance and if anyone else had to find a place to stay I would be doing them a dis-service if I didn't tell them to stay here.

My girlfriend and I spent three nights here in April 2009. Overall our experience here was nice. The rooms were small as expected but there was free internet, a fully bathroom, a bed and big chair to sit on. It's not extravagant but it suited our needs just nicely.Only complaints which none were a big enough deal for me to worry about if I went there again, is that some of the other guests were quite noisy during the morning and the hotel is somewhat far from a subway station. However, for 99% of the time it wasn't too noisy and a walk to the subway station is a good way to start a morning or end an evening.Overall, I was pleased with my stay at Sakura Hotel.

We stayed on this place for a total of three nights. The rooms and shared bathroms are small but comfortable and very clean. Has free wi fi and offers pcs with internet access on the lobby for a low price. The staff is very friendly and helpful. Plus the location is excellent, just three blocks away a major subway station. It also offers cheap meals and a very cheap breakfast of unlimited toasts and coffee/tea. It is also very close to a supermarket, a convenience store and restaurants. We would certainly go again if we return to Tokyo.

The Sakura hotel is more like a hostel - but a very nice one at that.Our room was very small, but you don't go to Tokyo to stay in your room. The bed was quite comfortable and the room was air conditioned for comfort.The toilet and shower facilities are all shared, but are cleaned daily and I was quite impressed with the level of cleanliness. The staff are EXCELLENT!! All speak good english and they were very helpful at all hours - the Sakura Hotel is 24 hours in the bar/cafe area. The hotel is in Jimbocho which isn't a nightlife area, but it is close to the subway and only a few stops away from all areas you'll need to go. We did manage to find a couple of very traditional bars tucked in downstairs rooms in the local area. We truly loved this hotel, as we met quite a few travellers from all over. I would highly recommend this hotel for younger travellers.

Sakura Hotel is not a Hotel. You share a shower and toilet with around 20 other guests on your floor. The double bed room is NOT big enough for 2 people, I recommend spending another 190Yen and getting a twin instead. (we switched part way through our stay)The only thing that stops this place from calling themselves a hostel is that they do not have any sort of kitchen facilities and they clean the rooms daily, however they did offer to us that we can use their grill (a small microwave grill oven thing) but when I witnessed others trying to use it, they told them they weren't aloud to and tried to charge them. That went out the window. I recommend using a sleeping bag as you get a very small duvet which for my 5ft height only covered me from my shoulders to my ankles. My husband was freezing most of the night, he's around 6ft. Dont count on air con working unless you can read Japanese.Otherwise somewhat good location, was close to subway, we recommend using Jimbocho Subway Station gate 1 instead of the suggested gate 6 as this is much closer to the hostel.

We stayed in a double room, which was big enough for a bed and standing room next to the bed. We were travelling light, so it was fine. We only used the room to sleep, we were out and about the rest of the time.The room was smallllllll and a bit stuffy, but it was cleaned daily, there were shared toilet and shower facilities, which is fine in theory but we were fighting for access with a massive high school group who were also on our floor. Breakfast downstairs was simple but cheap, unlimited coffee/tea refills and toast once you'd paid your small fee. Free wireless access downstairs was also a big bonus, and something we really appreciated.It's located close to a few subway stations, and fairly centrally placed, not far from the Imperial Palace East Gardens. Staff are really friendly, and everyone speaks English and Japanese. Lots of information about Tokyo is available at the desk and the staff were happy to help out.We were happy with the place, particularly for the price, and would probably stay again.

Sakura Hotel offers basic accommodation with low rates and a great location. You get what you pay for, however. The rooms are clean, but very small (only fits a bed and enough room to walk past it), even for Japan. Toilets and showers are shared, which is not so bad as they were cleaned daily. The wash basins are right out in the corridor, however. It was pretty weird to stand there brushing one’s teeth right next to another guest. Towels are not included but can be rented (almost for free, merely 100 yen per towel).We chose Sakura Hotel because it is called a hotel and I dislike hostels. It felt much more like a hostel than a hotel however, so the name is rather misleading. For a hostel, it was ok.The staff speaks English, and is really helpful and service minded. They seemed slightly undermanned at times though. There is a café/bar, but it was unmanned most of the time, which meant that you’d have to call for the person at the front desk to come and take your order. He/she would have to leave the front desk (possibly with people waiting in line) just to make your cappuccino or whatever. Felt kind of weird. There is a basic breakfast served in the morning (included in the price if you stay in a single room, otherwise costing a mere 315 yen). It is very basic (tea/coffee and toast), but it is nice to get something before going out sightseeing. The location of the hotel is excellent in terms of transportation. Although there is not much happening in the Jimbocho area, the hotel is only a few minutes' walk from Jimbocho station, from which you can easily get to more interesting neighborhoods. The subway system is easy to understand. Just make sure to get a pasmo card, and you won’t have to worry about transfers and costs. All in all, Sakura Hotel is a fine place to stay if you are on a tight budget and don’t mind staying at a hostel. For my own part, if I had known how low prices actually were in Tokyo, I would have paid up to stay at a real hotel instead.

This was a bad experience from the start! When we (My boyfriend and I) first arrived, they could not even find our reservation and claimed that we didn't have one. I had to use their computer to pull up my email and show them the email confirmation THEY sent me. We finally got a room...not the one we wanted. The whole floor smelled like body odor / football locker room. It was so bad we had to go out and buy an air freshener from 7-11. The room was the smallest Tokyo room I have ever seen. We stayed in about 4 places while we were traveling through Japan, and this "hotel" was the worst. It was an experience that we would like to forget. The only plus...it's close to the train. Would not reccommend this place to my worst enemy.
Good price and location but unfortunately there is quite a serious bed bug problem. For this reason alone I would not stay here again or recommend it.

The dorms are in the basement, one female dorm and one male dorm. No windows, a bit damp. It was smelly when you first enter the dorm, but after you turn on the air-conditioner for a while, it was OK. Curtains for beds were shown in their website, but there was none, only hooks where curtains used to be (if ever).

I stayed 6 nights in Sakura Hotel by myself. It was very difficult for me to pick a hotel as Tokyo is such an enourmous place but I liked Sakura's website and the price was right for a budget traveler like myself.I arrived Tokyo by train from Nagoya, and getting around first with a big backbag in July heat in rush hour Tokyo was rather challenging. Despite of the instructions I had printed out (which were not very specific as I trusted I could find the place as it was close to the station) I had major difficulties finding Sakura at first. I managed to get to the Jimbocho metro station and although Sakura was very close to it, I almost gave up and slept on the street instead :) The Japanese aroud either knew nothing, spoke no English or were pointing at all different directions!Anyway after finding Sakura I had a friendly welcome and got my room. It was teeny tiny but I didn't anticipate spending much time there anyway. There was just enough room for a single bed and walking past it. The room also had tv. The window was covered because of some construction they were making so I saw no light at all. It felt like staying in a closet but I didn't mind too much although I would have appreciated some daylight. I got a hair drier from the desk, and the air conditioning worked well. In July in Tokyo air condition is a must... The showers and bathrooms were shared and in the same floor. They were always clean and nice. The room had a rope and slippers so you could just put them on going to shower. Breakfast included to the private room rate and Sakura had a nice and often busy cafe-bar downstairs to have it. Basically it was toast and coffee, but that was good enough and it is always nice to get something before leaving. There was also internet but using it was very expensive.Overall, I had a pleasant stay in Sakura. It was far from luxury but for a little budjet hotel it did its job well. As a solo traveler I felt safe, comfortable and welcome. I would recommend Sakura to travelers like myself that need a modest and reasonably priced place.

The Sakura Hotel, Jimbocho is an excellent budget hotel. It is really cheap for Tokyo and although the rooms are quite small they are functional and spotlessly clean. The bed size wasn't really a problem for us and we're quite tall.The hotel staff were friendly and all seemed to have good English, which is handy. The front desk is manned 24 hours and the cafe is 24 hours but I didn't observe anyone using it really late at night apart from using the internet.There's a few computers for internet use, the charge is ￥100 per 10 minutes which isn't great (compared to the fantastic internet cafe prices in Tokyo) but fine if you just want to check your email.The showers and toilet facilities are shared which I was apprehensive about at first but there were never any problems with this and they were cleaned daily. Good water pressure in the showers. Towel hire is ￥100 which I didn't think was very good since it is called a hotel rather than a hostel, I feel that if you have a private room, with the extra you're paying compared to the dormitories you really could do with getting a couple of towels included.Breakfast was ￥315 per person but all you get is toast. There's a loaf of bread and a toaster and little packets of butter and jam. There's a large selection of tea which is included as breakfast and also packets of dried soup granules. The breakfast wasn't BAD as such but not really worth paying for. Would be fine if it was complimentary.Good location right next to the Jimbocho subway line where you can get to anywhere you want to in Tokyo once you work out the subway system! If you stand around any station looking confused then you're basically guaranteed to have someone try to help you and then you'll figure out what you're doing. God bless the person that decided to put the subway lines in romaji as well as kanji!Overall this was a nice place to stay on a budget. If what you want is a clean and cosy room for the night then that's what you get. I would stay here again because it was clean and the price was good.

Hello!Having stayed at Sakura Hotel on numerous occasions I can recommend it to travelers the world over! The place is cheaper than the ladies of Shinjuku, and that's pretty cheap for Tokyo! The rooms are clean with a daily wake up call by their friendly cleaning staff who barge into your room unannounced while you are lying naked in your bed or in an intimate moment with a lady friend, I am a ladies' man after all! The desk staff are always friendly. Dealing with your problems with a smile and no thanks necessary. A "Continental Breakfast" (which I believe is Japanese for Toast and orange juice) is provided in the mornings to guests. PROTIP: The staff don't check if you're staying at the hotel, so if you're staying at the Hilton or Mandarin Oriental and feel like a free breakfast stop by, no one will notice! Toilet and shower facilities are shared and if you are a voyeur this hotel will be ideal as there are windows on the toilet doors that, if you press against hard enough, will allow you to see what's going on inside! They are cleaned daily and always in pristine condition.TVs are provided in the rooms with pay TV available from vending machines on the floors. The channels that this gives you is some sport and a whole load of pornography, which is nice.All in all I would stay at the Sakura Hotel everytime I come to Japan! Well done.

Great budget hotel in a central location in Tokyo. Rooms cover anything from singles to group dorms and everything is very clean and neat. Decent showers, English speaking staff and no curfew. There's also free tea and breakfast. A good base to explore the city.

My husband and I spent a great week staying at the Sakura Hotel in Tokyo. It's great value for money in Tokyo terms. Be cautious if you like a lot of space though, because the rooms are very compact. The staff are very friendly, the rooms and shared bathrooms were clean and tidy, and the location is fantastic - it's in the heart of the Jimbocho book district, only a couple minutes walk from the subway, from where you're only another couple of minutes from Shibuya, Shinjuku and Harajuku. I'd definitely stay here again.

This place is just what a budget traveller to Tokyo needs. Its cheap, the rooms are basic but perfect for the traveller, and the recepetion desk in manned 24 hours with the most helpful people. Specifically Nori who gave us great advice on our stay in Tokyo. Its location in Jimbocho is great too as you are close to the subway and only a few stops to all the attractions. I give it a double thumbs up.

We stayed here for our last night in Japan. The staff was very helpful and accomodated us for an early check in. They were also very helpful with directions and for information.The room was spacious, but stank of stale smoke. Beds were comfortable, 4 bunks in a private room. Bedding was included but if you want a towel its 100 Yen extra.It felt like we were in a hostel or a college dorm rather than a hotel.This chain also does a hostel which we stayed at the week previous and was FAR superior and cheaper.

What I was most impressed about this hotel was the friendly staff who always went beyond their duties to make my stay as wonderful as possible. They were most helpful with directions, and general information, and even printed out a map from the internet for us! This is much more than I expected from any hotel front staff, esp. having stayed in many hotels in Europe.However, the downside is that the room we had was really small! I could barely walk with a suitcase on the floor! We had to prop the suitcase up every time we're in the room, just so we can walk around the room. But the rate was cheap, and I could live with a small room, only needing it to sleep.The bathrooms were clean and tidy.The hotel is only a short walk to the train station (Jimbocho - if I remember correctly).Overall I would recommend this hotel for any budget-conscious traveller needing a clean room for a night, wiht the added bonus of extra friendly staff.

Cheap for Tokyo and fully acceptable. But just a place to stay. You cannot spend time in the little room, but can hang out in the cafe downstairs. It is clean and not too hard to find. Tiny rooms with shared bathrooms. Staff are friendly and speak English. I had no problems at all.
